reviewText:
Ok i've only played this game for sub 1 hour but i can already put together a review (i will update it when needed)

For those giving it a thumbs up yes with out even actually playing the PC port yet simply because this is Disgaea you are all to be ignored. Seriously why thumbs up a game simply based on the franchise alone? that's like thumbing up Dragon Age 2.....simply because it's the 2nd Dragon age agme and DAO was amazing.

Those looking for a genuine review with harsh truths please look here.

NOTICE! Yes this is Disgaea in all of it's glory yes i love the franchise i've owned every game to date excluding the DS port because...well...didn't have a DS at the time lol But i'm a die hard fan of the franchise and was soooo excited when i saw this listed that for the first time in at least 5 years since SKYRIM i pre-ordered a game.

NOW THAT THATS OUT OF THE WAY.

This game has a TON of issues

Graphical issues come down to 3 major and i do mean major problems
SSAO as people have pointed out breaks the visuals entirely with graphical glitches like messed up black lines all over the place. Turnning this off in turn removes the graphical glitches but SSAO should NEVER be the cause of such a thing and thus needs dire fixes.
Resolution: this is probably the biggest one because it's tied to a bunch of problems. For starters, trying to run this game in full screen (there is no borderless? why?) completely breaks the game entirely. Upon going into full screen (for me) the game minimized......and refused to come back up......when ever i tried to maximize the window again it would just go right back down after a few seconds and the ONLY way i got it to stay up long enough to go back into windowed mode was to rapidly spam click my mouse on the window as it came up. it was extremely frustrating and this was all with in the first few seconds of loading the game up for the first time NOT EVEN IN GAME YET TECHNICALLY.
now back to the resolution issue. This port is clearly a port from the PSP or DS version of the game because OH GOD the graphics are soooo blurry. Turning off every graphical enhancement makes it look worse like it's running sub 480p and resizing the window just makes it even more stretchy and blurry. Character filter is absolutely pointless beause regardless of it being on or off the characters are pixelated to no end. Seriously they NEED to update the sprites for this game to play it on PC.
the third graphical issue is more on a performance side of things. the menus take FOREVER to bring up and the scrolling text for things like tutorials and talking to NPCs in general do not have a speed adjuster. You can not alter this so if you accidentally talk to that one NPC that just won't stop talking....guess what? .....tough luck....you're stuck spamming your buttons away until the text goes away. PATCH IN SCROLLING TEXT SPEED OPTIONS PLEASE!

Now onto the rest of the....issues....
controls. if you have a regular controller you are set, it's fairly easy to figure out the game with that. If you're on a mouse and keyboard like myself, yes you have rebindable keys, BUT THE BUTTON PROMPTS ON SCREEN DO NOT MATCH YOUR KEYBOARD HOTKEYS. To skip tutorial story stuff when selecting a map it says 4? i pressed 4....nothing happened......what does this 4 mean? OH it means the 4th button for your CONTROLLER. Good job! SO IT DOESN'T REFLECT WHAT KIND OF CONTROLS IM USING. On the flip side this is just a minor inconvenience as the menus and game as a whole can be completely played and controlled via mouse. Your keyboard doesn't even need to be touched as a matter of fact. the menus are accessed via left click over a character and right click over an open space to bring up the regular main menus for ending your turn or swapping out equipment and checking on character stats. But as i pointed out, the menus and controls as a whole are just sooo off in terms of responsiveness. you can click twice on the screen and nothing happens when trying to pull up the main menu. it's very frustrating when the game itself runs at a perfect 60FPS for me. This is the first time a Jrpg of any kind has run so smoothly in terms of framerate on PC for me since most Japanese game developers don't put much effort into optimization in general for PC. Then again considering how old this game is IT SHOULDN'T BE SHOCKING THAT IT RUNS AT 60FPS.

Seeing as i have less than 1 hour of gameplay i have no clue what the rest of the game is yet but just think.....it took me nearly one hour just to get into the game, get past the first 2-3 battles.......and create my first character........HOW!? I CAN DO THIS SO MUCH FASTER ON MY PS3 OR PS2! It's soooo frustrating because this franchise is my favorite one....period....nothing on my games list compares to how much i like this franchise as a whole. So please NISA....FIX THIS GAME SO WE CAN PLAY IT PROPERLY ON PC!

yes i will say i recommend this game, BUT THIS IS A HEAVY HEAVY WARNING THAT THIS GAME IS NOT A GREAT OR EVEN GOOD PORT. THIS GAME IS SLOPPY ON PC. SO TAKE MY WARNING SERIOUSLY. The game at launch is not worth the 20$ they are asking for even tho the franchise as a whole is well worth the 60 they generally charge for each new game.
voteText: 3 of 4 people (75%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
Now for you guys who look at all the negitive reviews, look at the date of them. I'm willing to place 5 bucks that they were made within the first week of release, and rightfully so.
Incase you didn't get this game on day one, it was awful. But that's a thing of the past, and most of the negitive reviews are moot.

Now the accual review. The score system is a 1-10 system, with 5 being average. anything above 5 is good, anything below 5 is bad.

Story 7
Gameplay 8
graphics 3 (it's an old game, thats ususally the thing that suffers the most)
Music 6
Characters 6
Humor 8
Difficulty 7 (enemy attacks sting, and many levels require thinking over just overpowering. the first boss will show you what I mean ;} )
Time Investment 9.5 (single player only doc's it half a point, but it's still a fun game even with 200+ hour investments)

Overall opinion, a solid game whos graphics have suffered some from its age, but everything else is much harder to age. Good level design will always be good level design, good music will always be good music, etc. A good game to play when you got an hour or 2 with nothing to do very often, like after a hard day at work or school.
voteText: 3 of 4 people (75%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
Ever since the PSP, I've been playing this series and now I get to have it for the PC!  You know, for just in case the PSP breaks and nobody's selling them anymore.

It's silly, goofy, challenging, entertaining, and just plain fun.  If you're into a strategy game that doesn't take itself too seriously, but takes the SRPG genre seriously, I'd recommend it.

HOWEVER, DOT DOT DOT

I felt that there's been a few features taken out.  I know simplicity's the spice of life with some games, but I don't know if that applies to this game.  I have mixed feelings about this and this is the only thing preventing me from giving the game a 5.

With that said, I give it 4 prinnies out of 5.

reviewText: Grade: 9/10\nReasoning: This will be a long review. For the record, I had played through both Hour and Afternoon of Darkness. As my own exprience, I had beet Prinny Baal within 30 hours of the game. That was due to insane transmigration and basically me running it on purpose. If this is your first time through the game, expect 100+ hours of gameplay for main story and Etna Mode. Otherwise, if you have played this before only get it if it is on sale. Not only does it keep the majority of the original bugs but introduces new ones. However the new layout seems great. Overall I recommend this, but beware if you have played it before. If you are new, take your time. Explore the mechanics and the world.

reviewText:
First and foremost let me get this out of the way as it seems to be one of the most disuccsed issues...  So far I've logged ~10 hours on Disgaea for the PC and I haven't found any graphical or sound issues.  I did follow some of the advice posted in other reviews about modifying the graphical settings so that very well may have helped.

For the game itself, so far I'd give it a 10/10.  Personally, unless I played an old school rpg/jrpg in the past I can't get into it.  Disgaea has pulled me in.  Everything about it is very appealing to me, the variety of monsters/allies you can create, the dark assembly, being able to clear levels inside of items to make them stronger, etc.  It's a lot of grind but I have a feeling I'm going to play it for a long time.

I hope we get to see more disgaea games on steam!

reviewText:
This game runs Flawless on the newest Generation Video cards AMD r9 3xx and Nv 9xx
Any older generation cards have Frame issues.

This is NOT the Games fault. The soruce of all major graphic issues lies within the OpenGL Drivers that AMD/NV supply with there windows drivers.

All PS2/PS3 Exclusive ports are based on a Modified Linux OS, and modified OpenGL driver and when porting to pc 80% of the time devs DO NOT recode the game for DX but instead reuses the OpenGL api's.. How ever the OpenGL drivers for console are not the same OpenGL driver that both AMD and NV supply which is why the  game causing frame rate and other related issues.

best you can hope for is both AMD and NV update there OpenGL driver for there older cards or buy there latest Gen cards.

BTW game works flawless on my rig

AMD FX 8120,
GTX 960
Windows 10 x64 DX12 (OpenGL 5.0)

reviewText:
Very addicting game, my first look into the series, and a first look into the genre even.

+Charming characters
+Nice soundtrack
+Plays well, didn't take too long to figure out how the combat works, though there are some intricacies that you probably wont pick up until later
+Dual Audio (Japanese/English) for people who might want to hear the original voices

+/- Grindy, not for people who want to wing it through a game without some grind
+/- Not really a complaint just be sure to save often it doesn't auto save, only pops up a save option at the end of chapters

-The mouse being always active unless disabled is annoying, if your mouse hovers over an enemy it will always try to target that even if you only use keyboard for everything
-Unplugging or changing your audio source will crash the game 100% of the time, at least for me it always does.
-Apparently you could skip animations in some versions of this game, but not in this one; some of the animations are really quite long so I would like to see this added
voteText: 5 of 8 people (63%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
I pre-ordered the game
My Impression:Overall, I was very very pleased to see Disgaea come to the PC. Welcome back to the front of the Strategy RPG pack, Disgaea. We missed you.

Part of what distinguishes Disgaea from more run-of-the-mill SRPGs is its wicked sense of humor, which makes just unveiling the story a treat.

I have played Disgaea 1-4, unfortunately haven't played 5 yet. I have had no problems with the port and have 6.5 hours into the game as of the time writing this.


Positive:+ Stayed true and is what you expect if you played Disgaea 1.
+ One of the best SRPGs you'll find
+ Great story with dark humor
+ Steam trading cards
+ Achievements
+ Replayability
+ PRINNIES

Negatives:- Price, I think it's a bit high, however, I wanted to support the future of more PC ports
- Controls can be a bit awkward at first with the keyboard. My system is to use only keyboard. I use the mouse if I am targeting during a battle. NiS could patch it so it is simplified by having WASD move the camera and the mouse do the actions, sort of like a CIV 5 type control system.
- I think some of the character graphics are still pixelated even after the port

Above Average Game Dood!: 7/10

I don't regret pre-ordering the game and I hope there are more PC ports of classic RPGs. I would recommend getting this at discount if it is your first time playing this sort of game. If you have played the series before, you should definitely get it, dood! Arguably the greatest and most substantial strategy RPG you'll get on the PC.

I never experience any type of video issues that was expressed by other uses. I hear a fix for it is disabling Depth of Field and SSAO. I have VSYNC off as well and it runs at 60FPS and no problems at all.

reviewText:
NVIDIA master race reporting in

Danganronpa and now Disgaea, 2016 is turning out to be a great year for PC gaming.

Game works wonderfully well, the amount of negative reviews over FPS for a 13 year old game is hilarious.

Not the most polished port of course but runs smooth enough and nothing is bugged out completely. Runs great! from what I have read the main issue seems to be FPS (which isn't an issue at all for me) and whoever is using an AMD card lmao, so if you have a problem with either you should be find something else to play. Remember, there is a refund system for a reason.

Hopefully the negative reviews won't stop Disgaea from releasing more games within their franchise. Disgaea is the king of turn based combat and the character interactions combined with the story is always entertaining enough to keep me entertained. A classic gem that hopefully will not be forgotten now that it has finally found its place within the PC Gaming community. Bring on more

reviewText:
EDIT: With the recent update, nearly all issues I had are gone. The game now runs fine whether using new textures or old textures (for me at least). The only issue I still have is screen tearing, regardless of whether V-sync is on or off, but hopefully that will be fixed, and that alone is not enough for me to not recommend the game.

In terms of gameplay, these options would be welcome additions:

-It would be nice to be able to use the high quality character portraits with the old UI.
(I prefer the old UI design, but not the lower quality character artwork.)
-Ability to change color of menu windows. I'd prefer the option for the new menu UI with black backgrounds and white text.
-Option to speed up character movement. Similar to how the other games do it.
-Option to speed up text speed.
-Turning off the mouse cursor really should just remove it from the screen instead of disabling input from it, but leaving it on the screen.

I don't yet know if some of the characters you could recruit in the DS version that were not recruitable in the PSP version are available for recruiting in this game, but they should be. Note: You could battle against the recruitable characters in the PSP version, and they were fully coded, just not playable until the DS release.

------

Oudated:

First off, I'd like to say that if you can get past the issues, the game underneath is phenomenal. The soundtrack, story, characters, design are all fantastic. Though the game touts grinding, it is balanced in such a way that it becomes easier to gain levels quickly, the more you advance in the game. Well into the post-game, it's possible to gain thousands of levels in a few minutes.

However, as much as I'd love to recommend this game, unless you are hardcore fan of the series, it's not worth it in its current state, as it has a lot of problems (as others have made clear). With pretty much every setting off, it worked fine for me. However, some settings just flat out make the screen go black. The game looks decent with New Map Textures" on
recommended: but it halves my framerate for essentially better looking backgrounds. With "Old Map Textures
hoursPlayed: it runs fine, but you get PSP textures. There are issues with screen-tearing, especially in the hub, even with Vsync on. Other reviews indicate that people with far better PCs are having much worse issues.

reviewText:
In terms of the gameplay itself, it is a straight port of Afternoon of Darkness, which I recommend to anyone looking to pick up the Disgaea series.

I do like the attempt at making keyboard and mouse controls work. It falls short, but shows a lot of promise if they ever go back to make it more responsive. As of this post, it seems the mouse controls don't always register at first, and it's too easy to accidentally undo an action. I'm just happy the keyboard binds can be changed.

Graphically, the game can't handle Vsync, Depth of Field and SSAO that well ._. If you have problems with lag, those are the things you might wanna turn off first. NIS America has stated in the community hub that they plan on fixing the graphical issues, so here's hoping they deliver >.>

As I said it falls short, but if you can work around the graphical issues and the mouse problems, it's still a good game. I would wait a month or so before buying this port, though.

EDIT: NIS America has announced a patch to be released March 2nd for some of the issues people have been having with the game, and aims to fix them entirely as time goes on.

I originally did NOT recommend this port, but with the amount of contact they're keeping with the player base in their community page, and the dedication they're putting into fixing this game (something I hardly ever hear about from devs, especially so soon after launch day), I feel they deserve the benefit of the doubt.

reviewText: I love Disgaea, in fact I already own the PS2 AND PSP version of this game, but this port is not great. I was looking forward to the mouse controls, as I feel SRPGs can be controlled extremely well with the mouse, and I was throughly dissappointed. Said controls are excessively touchy, and have caused several poor movements (lift and throw) already (5 chapters in), and 2 glitches, one of which crashed my game. However, the instant saving is phenominal, and I would love to see more of the features from other games implemented, such as the more forgiving movement (obviously you can cancel your movements, but in later installments you can just re-move until you actually act). I also would really like to see more of the series ported to the computer, espcially if they work on the mouse controls more.\n\nTLDR: If you own another version, don't bother. If you don't, it's a great game, would reccomend.

reviewText: After the recent patches, the game runs silky smooth like butter, but one issue I feel I need to address is speed, (ironically) specifically, message speed and attack animations. Don't get me wrong, the game is still great, and I love it dearly, with over 500 hours put into this game alone on ps2, but it makes me kinda just want to play an emulated version, just so I can hold down space to speed up the fights. reviewText:
The oldest game in the series, and as such is not as complex as the other games in the series. Despite being an inferior game to it's sequels in almost every way Disgaea 1 is still an amazing game that can get a lot of mileage out of anyone willing to spend time on it.

Often times I hear people complaining about grind and how it's never a good thing, but really grind is at the core of the Disgaea series, but it's been refined in such a good way. It's as if someone out there went through the effort of figuring out how to make grind appealing.

I can't really pinpoint one thing in particular that makes the mundane task of grinding much more entertaining, but if I had to compare it to something it'd be the progression in things like Cookie Clicker without the whole clicking or automatic aspect. I mean this in the sense that when things seem like they're about to slow down there were typically many ways to make the game go faster. But really, I suppose that the best thing about all of this is that grinding is completely optional and if you strategize properly you'll never have to grind for anything in the storyline. There are many end game bosses that require bosses, but you'll never be absolutely required to grind unless you strategize poorly and end up getting your characters massacred every time you play.

One of the neat features this game has is something called the Item World" and what that is is a world inside of an item in the game
date: and every single item in the game has it's own item world which is 100% randomized every single time. These item worlds have monsters that progressively get stronger based off of the quality of the item you're in as well as the floor you're on. Items can have upwards of 100 floors based on their rarity
recommended: and going up in floors increases the stats of items and grants you a chance at running into the "Residents" of the world. Completely seperate from the enemies you will encounter in the item world
hoursPlayed: Residents are things that can be subdued and transferred from item to item and give really good bonuses such as elemental resistance
voteText: higher stats
helpfulPercent: and increased EXP gains.\n\nReincarnation is another feature that this game has to offer. Although the level cap is 9999 you can still go even further
votesHelpful: with reincarnation resetting your level but netting you extra points to spec into your stats depending on what your total level was. You'll also get a bonus to your base stats depending on how high they were when you reincarnated. Reincarnating as a generic may also allow you to promote that unit to a higher ranking if they meet the requirements
votesTotal: which allows you access to higher stats
votesFunny: sometimes better spells
commentsCount: and if applicable better weapon mastery.\n\nThere's really so much to this game that I could go on for days. The game is amazing and if you're looking for a way into the series this is probably one of the better places to start since it's all uphill from here. Disgaea 1 also has the best story and cast in the entire series and everything else after it in that regard isn't as good
column16: so I really hope you're not looking for story in the later titles because they might as well not be there."

reviewText: Still a very enjoyable strategy RPG classic with a ton of content, likable, goofy characters and a colourful style. If you don't mind a bit of grinding here and there it's worth a buy.\n\nKeep in mind it's a bit of troubled release though. Even though most of the issues on launch are patched now it's still advised to exercise some caution.

reviewText:
OK this game had problems at launch techincal problems and I'm not going to go into that because frankly I haven't expierienced them.

HOWEVER I can go into the status of the port as I see it now and honestly for a ps2 game of this age that was never meant to be on PC at all. This is pretty good, the keys are rebindable, there is mouse support and if you wanted to you could use the mouse for everything. The sprites are a little low rez, but this is just a port not a remastering.

As far as I'm concerned, if you sidestep the port problems entirely like I did, this is a pretty good port for what its worth. If you run into those problems however, always remember steam refunds still exist and those problems should crop up VERY quickly and well within your first two hours of play.

Was pretty rough at launch, but the dev team has rapidly fixed every issue I had with the port.

Now, this is still Disgaea 1. There's been no gameplay updates to match the more recent titles in the series, no HD sprites, no new levels, nothing like that. reviewText:
Fun game if you're craving the Final Fantasy Tactics style game.  And this game competes in entertainment through humour and cool animations.

A definite pickup.

What sucks about the PC port you'll notice after you've beaten the game and trying to max out your character.  Spending an hour grinding levels only to have the game crash is NOT fun.  This happens consistent enough that you can expect the game to crash.

This is also very frustrating when you spend an hour leveling up your weapon skill only to have the game crash before you get the chance to save.

This happens frequently but doesn't take away from the initial gameplay when you're going through it the first time.

Still worth the buy despite the crashes... and hopefully they'll patch the problems with crashing on end game" gameplay."

reviewText:
When this game first came out, it exploded like a thrown prinny, and Master Etna was ♥♥♥♥♥♥, d00d.  But now it's transcended a few times, and has gained an S rank in Fun and SRPG goodness.

It's the first game in the series, so if you've been following the franchise (or NIS games in general) you might lament how the item worlds can be unwinnable or how the graphics aren't HD, but if you're new to it you're about to see the SRPG that made people rethink what they could do with a character and just how far they could go to max its levels.  Or its stats.  Or its items levels or its items stats or the levels of the innocent bystanders that live in the items that lend extra strength or the levels of attacks or dear god there are so many levels.

reviewText:
This is a direct port of the PS2 classic. If you're expecting new content (Aside from the additional content from the PSP port) then you will be disappointed.

That aside, this is a fantastic game. It ate my free time when I was younger and it will eat my free time again. It's a classic game for people that don't *just* grind, it's for people that *enjoy* grinding.

The story is enjoyable and can be played through without much grinding, but some of the additional content does require a bit of grind. There's afterstories, likeable characters and it's just generally a funny, likeable game. It has content for casual players, as well as content for people who don't mind a hardcore grind. If you've never played Disgaea before you should try it, no better place to start than here. If you have played Disgaea before, here it is again on PC. Time to grind.

reviewText:
I've been playing Disgaea for years now, so I'll state the non-story/gameplay stuff here.

There's still several things needed to be done to fix the bugs, but otherwise, it's still enjoyable. Mouse's input are quite annoying and I kinda wished I was able to just use the keyboards to name my character, instead of clicking/navigating through the screen

The game gets REAL heavy if you turn on SSAO,DoF and the End-Blur, it drops from 60 fps to 30 fps on my PC, and it gets heavier while on map with enemies, since the game gets slower, instead of running at a choppy frame rate.

Otherwise, it's a perfectly nice port of Disgaea's Afternoon of Darkness. I hope they patch these issues soon and port the other main series too

after all, this was their first port to PC, so they get an extra toleration bar from me

reviewText:
Anybody that knows me knows I have put FAR too many hours in Disgaea games - about 1500 hours in each minimum, including ports (excluding Disgaea 3 [didn't have a chance to play that :c], the Prinny games, and Disgaea Infinite), so I have a lot I can say about this game, and even though it's recommended from me, I have some bad things to say about my baby. But let's start with WHY you should play this game if you haven't:
~Hilarious story/characters
~Makes grinding actually fun
~Hundreds of hours of replayability
~90% of all the bugs have been fixed (all the lethal bugs should be gone now)

Now, why this game is bad from a Disgaea veteran's perspective:
~So many oppertunities to mod and add mods, gone to waste (subject to change later)
~It's the EXACT same as the PSP port, just less portable.
~Once you've played it as long as I have (30 combined story clears across all ports), it just becomes a chore to play again.
~There could have been SO many more achievements, but there aren't.

Really fun game, and definitely worth getting if you never played the PSP version. If you DO have the PSP version... request access from a friend's library, as the PSP version is pretty much the exact same but portable.
Still love you, Nippon Ichi Software <3
voteText: 1 person found this review helpful 1 person found this review funny

reviewText: I played this one back when it came out on PS2 and I fell in LOVE <3 <3 <3\n\nThe updates to the art are beautiful! I have never been a huge fan of dungeon crawlers. I love the old school RPGs like Final Fantasy, Chrono Trigger and Secret of Mana, but the creepy yet cute style of this game intrigues me enough to try it. I'm so glad I did! The storyline is wonderful. I loved the characters and the voice acting is amazing. It adds so much to the gameplay. I'm impatient and often find myself mashing the Next button during the longer dialog scenes. Not with Disgaea! I enjoyed every bit and would happily let it play out. 10 out of 10. I think I have over 60 hours logged on this one and I have so many more to look forward to!

reviewText:
Recommending this game was a close run thing.

I got it originally for the Playstation 2 back in the day, and that console died a while back. I also picked up the DS release, which had the added content of Etna's story mode. It's really no different from that release, and where it is, it's not necessarily in it's favour.

The reason I'd recommend it is the same reason I'd recommend those versions. The story is fun and engaging, the mechanics are deep enough to allow someone to really get into creating the fighters that they wish and it requires a real investment in time to get the most out of the experience.

The downside is that the steam release hasn't been done particularly well. The game is unstable, crashing out on a regular basis. This is still happening, several patches down the line. I realize that NIS are putting in the time and the effort to patch the game, and they've been doing good work on that. But frankly, a game that crashes out as often as this probably shouldn't have been released commercially yet. Half the recommended actions to increase stability involve turning off features that are meant to improve the user experience.
This game relies heavily on grinding, several of the achievements are named for exactly that. You cannot focus on grinding well when you're aware that you're likely to lose progress often, simply because the game crashed out before you can save.

Like I said, I would recommend this game, but that recommendation depends on your willingness to put up with the bugs. If they do release later titles, I'll probably get them too, but I really hope that NIS puts in more work on the port before release to ensure the game is as good as it should be.

reviewText:
While I was initially turned off from the game, because it performed very poorly, I have since re-bought the game, at full price even, as I had an itch to play it and was informed it worked better than it did.  I can thankfully say, that this is worth the $20 and works great now.

This is a review for people who don't know what this game all has.  Keep in mind, I am not an anime fan in the slightest, because of this, I'm very happy that there's a skip storyline option.  Something to note on this though, it doesn't skip introductions and outros for episodes, but it does kill all the filler before battles in the story.  You'll mostly know what's going on with the story because of this, but it does drag on.  A nice option you have with it being on PC, is you can alt-tab while it runs the story and the game will continue to go.  This is great for those especially annoying outros.

As for the game itself...ho-boy, there's a lot of content.  I've played this game pretty religiously in the past, I think the last time I beat the hardest boss I clocked in 104 hours or so.  There's a lot to this game if you really want to dive in, the story itself will take about 30-45 hours depending on how much you feel like grinding or get side tracked.  There's two story modes, one being really rushy and not that interesting, but still a nice addition and the regular campaign, as well as post-game content and something called the item world.

The story is pretty standard, you'll go through pre-determined maps to progress the storyline.  Some interesting concepts, that change pretty good to keep you thinking.  This is partly due to Geo Panels which are battlefield bonuses you can control to a certain degree.  Sometimes they're helpful, sometimes they aren't, you get a fair amount of control that's hard to explain without actually playing the game.

The post game content is presented in a similar fashion, when you unlock it, it has a few levels leading up to a boss usually.  These are side plots that can have their own ending, but often serve as very difficult encounters.  I really like these, in my opinion this is what you push content for.

Then there's the Item World, another difficult to explain concept that ends a lot of variety into the game.  It's a randomly generated map that's created when choose a weapon to enter.  The item generates floors and clearing each one is great for exp, getting new items and it also allows you to level up the weapon, making it even better than it was.  This is where you can spend a majority of the game, or you can also decide not to, I actually beat the game on my 104 hour save file without going into the item world, however if you really want to push your efficiency of your character/s as well as get the truly best gear available, you will have dive deep into the item world.

With all this there's also a court system, you can pass bills that affect the enemies, increase what you can find for items in the shop and so forth.  If you're having too easy of a time with the game, you can make the enemies harder by passing a bill, or you can make them easier, rebirth, improve your character in other ways and so forth.  It adds another layer to the game can affect all the other things to do.  What's fun too, is if you're having issues passing a bill, you can kill the senate.  These are demon politics afterall!

All in all, it's one of the best SRPGs you'll find around.  You don't have to worry about too much filler in between battles, the gameplay is very solid and there have been improvements that are found on this version.  I highly recommend it if you're into the genre, even if you don't care for anime.  And if you do, well that's good for you, will help you enjoy the story.

reviewText:
+++ The first Disgaea has the most charm of any title in the series. This holds true with the remake.
+ One of the better storylines, and still my favourite
+ The only game where Majins get some love
+ Heavy timing diagonal throwing action!
+ Captain Gordon, DEFENDER OF EARTH!
+ See the Prism Rangers before they had every colour
= Items are easy to max out
= Maxing characters with 186,000 stored levels is harder than in later titles
- Miss convenient gameplay additions
- Miss jumping in the overworld
- Based on the psp version, so no Plenair, Rosalin or Zetta...so far?? (no one cares about Adell)
- The Invasion From Within song isn't in this version
- As of this review, bugs, problems and a grind-killing damage number memory leak crash remain. Pretty Prinny remedies this and is highly recommended.

The verdict? Totally worth it, dood.

reviewText:
To start this off... Is this game perfect? No.
Do I enjoy it? Yes.

Since you are reading these reviews you must be torn to get this game or not. If you have only played the newer Disgaea games - Ie, 4.D2. and 5, I would stay away from the computer port, and just  emulate the psp/DS version of it, as it had a few nice Quality of life features, such as faster dialog. If you have played all of them before, give this game a chance.

Gameplay- Disgaea follows a typical TRPG system- Make unit, Select unit, Move unit, Kill unit. Gain exp... Oh, and throw Prinnys Dood. The place where Disgaea is different, is the exp system. Most games let you go to level 99, or if your lucky 999. Disgaea says no to that, with a soft level cap of 9999 and a 'optimal' level cap of  186,000.
Given that TRPG's are the best kind of RPG's I have to give this part a 9/10

Story- Demons, Demonesses, Angels, Flonnes, Prinnys. You play as Laharl; a 1313 year old demon child, who has just awoken from a 2 year slumber to find out that his father, King Krichevskoy, ruler of the Netherwold is dead. This has caused most of the Kings vassals to take off, or to try to take Laharls place as the overlord. Thus, Laharl needs to take the throme back by force.
8/10. Probably the best story in the Disgaea series,  A good mix of comedy, story telling, and drama.
(My personal story ranking- 1,2,5,4,3, D2)

Port- I have not put enough time into the game to give this too much thought, however, it seems to be an almost identical port to the Psp version, with a few extra options added. The options are- New maps, new sprites (Which look terrible) New menus, V-sync, screen size, SSAO, DOF, Screen Blur, and Shadows. (30-60 FPS)
7/10. Not much to say, seems like a straight port.

Performance- This is where the problem lies for some people. Do you have an AMD GPU? Your in for a bad time. Do you like the new features they added? (V-sync, SSAO, ect) Your in for a bad time. Luckily for me, I have neither of the main problem causers, so the game runs at a smooth 60 fps.
9/10. This score is only based on the performance I get.

Overall score- 8/10.  It's a decent port of a great series with a few quality of life features missing. If you like the series and want NIS to port more of the series, go ahead an give em $20.

(For context- Running Windows 7, GTX 970, 16GB, i7-4770)

reviewText:
As many of you are aware by now, there are some pretty big issues with this port for some players (myself included) regarding dropped frame rates.  With any luck, they will soon be addressed and should not distract from what's important...

The game itself is amazing!  It's exactly how I remembered playing it back on the PS2 all those years ago.  If you're looking for a faithful version of it (and hate the idea of buying an old system or *shudder* a PSP), then this will be the place to be!  Yes, I am a fan-boy of the franchise which really means I'd be first in line to bash this game if it were bad.  The humor is on point and I just can't say enough great things about it.

Now, the bad.  Yes, as stated earlier there are some FPS issues that will hopefully be fixed.  Another major sour point I keep reading in reviews is that the Steam controller doesn't work for the game.  I will debunk this right now.  All it takes is maybe 2 minutes in the controller setting to set it up and then you're out the door running.

*EDIT*  I've found that if you are opted into the Steam Beta, it will lag out this game.  I opted out of it and since then I've had a steady 60FPS, even during big effects.

reviewText:
I loved this game on the PS2, and a PC release is great.
There's a lot of bugs, though.
I don't have the graphical glicthes everyone else seems to have, but the mouse is slippery, the buttons all stick (checked on multiple computers, it's in game), and I've encountered a strange bug where on the overworld, Laharl only walks to the right.
These, however rather frustrating, can be forgiven.
I missed this game so much, and they didn't change much aside from some updated graphics. It's exactly how I remember and I still love it to death.
So, if you liked it on the PS2, be careful, but I still find it just as enjoyable.
I do think the bug fixes are a must, though!

reviewText:
Disgaea is a fun parody of the RPG and anime genre, and tells its story through a colorful cast of characters and visuals.

Characters:
The cast consists of Laharl, a bratty, but oddly cool demon prince; Etna, his scheming vassal and lastly, Flowne, a loving angel-in-training who they call Love Freak". Like I mentioned before
date: the cast are parodies of anime and RPG tropes
recommended:
but they retain enough of their own personality to feel like actual people instead of simply jokes. Even the secondary characters are given variation in both their personalities and design. By that I mean there are no throwaway characters because each one feels so unique and different.

The Story:
Campy and purposefully silly
hoursPlayed: Disgaea’s story is rife with comedy and references
voteText: but not so much as to ruin the atmosphere. The serious moments are kept appropriately dramatic
helpfulPercent: but there are times when something goofy happens that can break the tension. These times; however
votesHelpful:
are kept out of the more serious moments.

Mechanics:
Despite its age the game’s system is still fun and its various features like “The Item World”
votesTotal: “The Dark Assembly” greatly spice up the game.  What would be an otherwise tedious grind is saved by conveniences and distractions offered by your ability to bribe or crush the assembly
votesFunny: or grab some stuff in the Item World."

reviewText:
The PC release had a rough start but a week later and several patches it's running better than before.
This port may have had a rough start but with the pace they are fixing things i doubt i'd regret buying it.
A few more tweaks here and there and we'll have a solid game on our hands. Dood!

Even at its rough shape now I would still recommend this to any Srpg fan.
Gameplay is a solid classic that still holds interesting mechanics like lifting/throwing and stacking characters
The Dark Assembly is also a unique piece where you propose and get the Senate to vote or beat them to submission.
Sound is just gorgeous (definitely why i pre-ordered)
Storywise, you will fall in love with the Netherworld and its cast of characters
Laharl and his distinct laugh, Etna and her schemes, as well as the game's mascot Prinnies - explosive demon penguins!
There is no shortage of unique and interesting characters to keep the story going; and
The sheer amount of Replayability is enough for generations to come.

reviewText:
Despite having horrible release day problems, NISA was quick to address the issues. They showed how much they care about the customers.

As for the gameplay, it is a very creative strategy RPG with a myriad of attack AoE's and the lift and throw system is pure innovation. I can't get enough of it. The magic tutoring system is also amazing. You can spend very little mana to get a good-for-nothing pupil, who will teach the master their spell type by standing close to them and it leveling to rank 1, then just delete the pupil to free up your character list. It's very complex and hard, but rewards creative thinking, which all RPGs need to do in my honest opinion.

As for the story, it's a hilarious parody of typical RPG plots. You'd love it if you like silly humor.

reviewText: I bought a PS2 three years ago from a thrift store just to play this game.  It's one of those few games where the first is better than the sequels.  I'm very glad they decided to release this one before any of the newer versions.  You can play the story, grind out levels, power up your items, and a ton of other things.  I personally like making a couple of my favorite characters bat-♥♥♥♥ insane powerful and just curb-stomping anything in my way.\n\nIf you like tactics style games, this is possibly the best one ever made.  It's certainly my favorite by a good margin.

reviewText:
To start this off... Is this game perfect? No.
Do I enjoy it? Yes.

Since you are reading these reviews you must be torn to get this game or not. If you have only played the newer Disgaea games - Ie, 4.D2. and 5, I would stay away from the computer port, and just  emulate the psp/DS version of it, as it had a few nice Quality of life features, such as faster dialog. If you have played all of them before, give this game a chance.

Gameplay- Disgaea follows a typical TRPG system- Make unit, Select unit, Move unit, Kill unit. Gain exp... Oh, and throw Prinnys Dood. The place where Disgaea is different, is the exp system. Most games let you go to level 99, or if your lucky 999. Disgaea says no to that, with a soft level cap of 9999 and a 'optimal' level cap of  186,000.
Given that TRPG's are the best kind of RPG's I have to give this part a 9/10

Story- Demons, Demonesses, Angels, Flonnes, Prinnys. You play as Laharl; a 1313 year old demon child, who has just awoken from a 2 year slumber to find out that his father, King Krichevskoy, ruler of the Netherwold is dead. This has caused most of the Kings vassals to take off, or to try to take Laharls place as the overlord. Thus, Laharl needs to take the throme back by force.
8/10. Probably the best story in the Disgaea series,  A good mix of comedy, story telling, and drama.
(My personal story ranking- 1,2,5,4,3, D2)

Port- I have not put enough time into the game to give this too much thought, however, it seems to be an almost identical port to the Psp version, with a few extra options added. The options are- New maps, new sprites (Which look terrible) New menus, V-sync, screen size, SSAO, DOF, Screen Blur, and Shadows. (30-60 FPS)
7/10. Not much to say, seems like a straight port.

Performance- This is where the problem lies for some people. Do you have an AMD GPU? Your in for a bad time. Do you like the new features they added? (V-sync, SSAO, ect) Your in for a bad time. Luckily for me, I have neither of the main problem causers, so the game runs at a smooth 60 fps.
9/10. This score is only based on the performance I get.

Overall score- 8/10.  It's a decent port of a great series with a few quality of life features missing. If you like the series and want NIS to port more of the series, go ahead an give em $20.

(For context- Running Windows 7, GTX 970, 16GB, i7-4770)

reviewText:
I loved this game on the PS2, and a PC release is great.
There's a lot of bugs, though.
I don't have the graphical glicthes everyone else seems to have, but the mouse is slippery, the buttons all stick (checked on multiple computers, it's in game), and I've encountered a strange bug where on the overworld, Laharl only walks to the right.
These, however rather frustrating, can be forgiven.
I missed this game so much, and they didn't change much aside from some updated graphics. It's exactly how I remember and I still love it to death.
So, if you liked it on the PS2, be careful, but I still find it just as enjoyable.
I do think the bug fixes are a must, though!

reviewText:
The game itself gets two thumbs up, but it's just not optimized yet.  It's always humorous when I play Witcher 3 at max specs, but I can't get over 20 fps when I switch over to Disgaea.  Don't write the game off, though.  Once it's patched up, I will sink 1000 hours into this game.

And just so people don't assume I'm runing a computer from 1980, these are my specs:

Win 10 Pro
GTX 980Ti
Inte. I7-4960 @ 3.60 GHz
32 GB RAM

Edit:
I've played enough of the game now to tell how good the port is.  In short, it's not great.  To those who feel that the mouse controls are bad, I agree.  However, turn off the mouse controls and just use the keyboard.  Moving around on a big map is a pain, but it's much better than the mouse controls.  7/10 for the port.

The game holds up well, though.  Some of the later games have some features that give them advantages; but as a stand-alone game, I still give it a 9/10.  This is a game about grinding, and it makes no apologies for that.  You can play through the core game with just Laharl, so people who don't like exploring the limits of the various systems will really hate this game.  Anyone who has ever complained you can just press x and win" will hate this game.

Edit2:
I've run into the same problem others have.  The game crashes after about an hour or so.  This effectively makes the item world off-limits.  This is very sad for me.  This is the perfect game to scratch that occasional grinding itch I get.  Hopefully they can fix this.  I still give the game a thumbs up

reviewText:
My critic review: http://www.cubed3.com/review/2663/1/disgaea-pc-pc.html

Okay, so... I loved Hour of Darkness, and then I loved it again when it was Afternoon of Darkness. And now I love it again, as it's now Disgaea PC. It's truly a game for hardcore gamers who don't merely tolerate but *relish* the grind, who have no qualms about dedicating three hours to gain a 0.01% stat increase, who want to power up characters to ridiculous degrees, and all that great stuff.

The only thing I'd add to my official review is that it seems to crash a lot lately, and this always seems to happen on the 10th floor of an Item World, when one of the monsters uses Air Assault. Sometimes it's a different ability, but it happens with some regularity. There's no Quick Save feature (Why not? This is 2016. You mean to tell me, NISA, that you can't have the game auto-save upon loading each new floor of the Item World, allowing us to resume from that floor in the event of crashing? Considering this is the PC version and crashes about once every 4 hours, I think it's prudent to have such a feature.), so if you make it to Floor 100 of an item and the game crashes, you're just ♥♥♥♥ed--all that grinding, gone. That's not acceptable in a game like this, where grinding is the main appeal. Grinding is certainly one thing--redoing a grind because the game crashed is yet another.

In honor of Disgaea, I can only score this game 357,477,952,188 / 498,110,387,298.

Fix the crashing, or implement an auto-save so that we can resume from the last floor we completed in the event of a crash. I've had this happen once at Floor 22/30, but I can't imagine how horrible it would be to have this happen on the 90th floor of a Legendary. It's already enough to make me want to stop playing in disgust, because the failure to include such an auto-save (a la the Final Fantasy re-releases, where Quick Saving deletes the save file as soon as it's loaded, to prevent save scumming) is a gross lack of consideration for the end users.

If you're not the type to get carried away in the Item World chasing after a total of 185,000 levels, then I can easily recommend Disgaea PC. If you *are* that type, then wait until it crashes less frequently, or until they've implemented an Auto-Save.

Or emu--I mean, just wait until they do something that shows they care about the countless hours of grinding that people are losing.

reviewText:
It's a pretty straight port of the PSP version, with keyboard+mouse support and the option to use upgraded map textures. Missing a couple of features, and appears to be running poorly on some peoples computers, which is unfortunate, as it runs perfectly fine on my rig. The best part, though, is running Disgaea at 1080p without any aliasing or jaggies, looks good and is now pretty much the definitive version of the game (in features and appearance!). Considering this is a port of a game which came to be in 2003, they certainly took their time getting it onto PC. Looks interesting to you and want to get into the series? This review will try to quickly give you an idea of the game without spoiling the things that matter.

As for the game itself, it's a heavily gameplay focused RPG with a story tailored to entertainment value. Things only get serious around the last few chapters. Disgaea heavily values the player, giving you a multitude of ways to strengthen your characters and eventually create a monstrosity that can one-shot everything. However, ther isn't much to guide you much making said monstrosity. These things are mostly for the hardcore audience, you can bring characters to level 9999, then bring them back to level 1 with bonuses to make them become even stronger. If you like streamlining in your games and having everything be simple to understand, this has very little. They explain the basic mechanics of the game, and let you figure out everything else and devise your own strategies, both in gameplay and system. You should not know everything about how to play Disgaea going into it for the first time. To close this off, I think it's a game that you should absolutely own if you enjoy customization, strategy RPG's and pushing the limits of a game.

By the way... This game is lacking in many convenience features that future games include to make things more fun or convenient. However I still reccomend playing this game first, as you could easily discredit the earlier games by playing more modern versions. There really are a lot of great features added in later releases, but you'll be missing out on a great game if you play them first.

reviewText:
If you haven't played any of the disgaea series before - this is the first in a line of great tactical games with it's first port to PC from it's PSP version, Disgaea Hour of Darkness. There haven't been any FPS issues since it was patched recently, but there are some crashes here and there so remember to save frequently.

The main story of the game can easily be finished without any grinding in a few hours with the final boss being level 90 in a game with a maximum level of 9999, but there's always more to do, as you'll likely lose yourself grinding levels and powering your items to beat the hardest boss. The main cast of characters are great, with their interactions being really entertaining, and there being a great amount of humor being thrown around the game. Although the game is rather old, it still holds up and hopefully there will be more ports of the disgaea series :)

reviewText:
I've loved SRPGs since Shining Force II on the Sega GameGear. Back in my console only days I enjoyed a plethora of titles from Altus, NI, Square, and many others. Since going (more or less) full PC I've been missing the ability to play one of my most beloved genres. Most SRPG titles on PC hadn't really been up to what I really missed. Then Disgaea was released for the PC.

If you are not familiar with Disgaea it is along running series of grind heavy SRPGs with a strong dose of humor. In the first title you play the son of the Demon Overlord who is going after the vacant crown. There are MANY challenges between you and the crown... some hard, some funny, many both.

Pros
They ported Disgaea to PC. If it does well they could port more titles!
It's the same game play as the original
Incredible replay value
Silly humor
Unique story
Randomly generated levels through the item world

Cons
Audio sometimes cuts out until the game is restarted
Some people report some slowdown bugs (though I haven't hit any)

Note
I do worry that the response by some players to some of the bugs might push the publisher back to being console only. That would be a disaster for SRPG fans. Yes, there are bugs but helping them run them down and fix is a better response. Unlike consoles there are thousands of possible system configurations with PC gaming.

reviewText:
The Disgaea series is absolutely among the cream of the crop for SRPGs. Crazy ways to get what you want, how you want. Humorous stories with some surprisingly emotional moments that make you adore the characters. Takehito Harada's varied, vibrant character designs. The catchy tunes by Tenpei Sato.

The original Disgaea, now ported here to Steam, is where it all started. The port's had a bit of a rocky start--mixed performance for many (but with temporary solutions present). NIS has thankfully made it clear (quickly and detailed, too) that they are aware and are working to solve the issues. That's plenty more initiative than other developers grant. Give it a go despite what you've heard; even if it doesn't work well on your system no matter what you try, it's still playable enough and there's an effort to fix out there.

As far as the first Disgaea compares to its peers, it certainly has one of the most well-woven marriages of story and characters in its grand scheme. Unfortunately, to be honest, having played the living daylights out of later games in the series, I found myself constantly missing nice things implemented later and the snail's pace by comparison. Don't let that deter you though, the first Disgaea is still an incredibly fine game and I just hope that later installments land on Steam as well!

reviewText:
Buggier than a sack full of ants!

I'm very sad to have to repoirt this, because I love the disgaea series is my favorite SRPG series. The problem is porting it to PC, it just isn't working for me. Some of you might be doing better, but the headache I'm getting from this port is terrible.

Some patches have been released, but there are more problems being made for each patch.

Crashes, controller issues, slow framerates, all problems I've had or am having.

The worst is my save data. It keeps making the game freeze. I try to load, and it freezes. Delete the save data and use the cloud backup, and it works a few times, only to do it again! Now, I've lost progress, albeit only a little, because the game froze when i tried to save! And I mean froze hard! Ctrl+alt+del to bring up task manager did nothing, alt-tab did nothing. I literally had to hold my power buttong down to power off, and reboot.

Disgaea is a great game, but the PC version it, at this time, a total waste. If you have a PS2, PSP, or DS/3DS, buy the versions for those consoles to play this game, as it is fun and funny. Your PC is better used for playing other games.

I may change this review if Disgaea PC becomes patched to stability.

reviewText:
No problems so far, game runs smoothly at 60HZ 1080p on my system (Win7 GTX750 i5-2500 8gb RAM). There is some screen tearing, Vsync fixes it, and has no negative impact on the game - no FPS drops, no slowdowns or anything. Seems like a good port so far.
I will update this if i encounter any problems.

UPDATE: there are some graphical artifacts in some places with SSAO on. There are some issues with mouse controls, for example, mouse clicking doesn't always work if your mouse pointer is not stationary. I've seen a number of reported problems on forum and in group chat, so i now can safely say that this port is definitely not flawless, even though i was lucky enough to not encounter most of the issues.
There were couple of dev representatives in group chat who were collecting feedback on problems people are having, hopefully it results in problems being fixed soon.
I will still leave this review as positive, but anyone looking to buy this game now should be aware of possible problems they may encounter.

reviewText:
TL;DR>Picks PSP with still functioning UMD drive and mint condition Disgaea 1 UMD*
>Checks stats
>Playtime: 1,274h 33m
>It's okay.

Well balanced tactical, turnbased RPG with gameplay comparable to Final Fantasy Tactics/Tactics Advance.



In depth version
Yet another PS2/3 Era game being remastered to be sold on the PC Master Race via Steam lately. If you're one of those that missed those eras *glances at dusty but working PS2 as well as PSP that was purchased specifically for the Disgaea ports* then GET IT NOW.

Storyline-wise, it's an excellent tale of a young (by demon standards 1,313 is young, apparently) demon prince waking up after sleeping for two years to find out his father is dead and all the overlord's vassals are gone. Heck, its a power struggle even - most of them are trying to take over the Netherworld instead of serving him. Time to beat them down, take his rightful place as the next Overlord and save the Netherworld from the machinations of an Archangel along the way. Despite the sounds of all of this, it manages to mantain a light hearted tone along the way, inserting all sorts of humor into the dialogue scenes. Enough to make you smile, but not enough to be tiresome. Total playtime can be around 40-60 hours from just running the story alone. The rest comes from the item world, optional postgame and how much you want to grind out 'perfect' characters.

As for the gameplay...it's pretty comparable to Final Fantasy Tactics. If you didn't play that, Disgaea is a turn based strategy that takes place on grid based maps involving use of units of certain classes to hammer one another until you win or get wiped. You can deploy a maximum of 10 units at any given time of various classes as either a Human unit or a Monster unit. Humans may equip different types of weapons and learn to master them at different rates based on class. For example, Larhal doesn't favor fist weapons but can still learn those at a significantly slower rate than spears or swords, his preferred weapons. Each level of weapon mastery (experience is granted by attacking with weapons, to a maximum of level mastery 255) translates to 5% bonus on the weapon class stats as well as additional special moves being unlocked at certain levels. That said, monsters do not have weapon mastery (though they have their own class of 'Monster Weapons') but instead have better stat growths to compensate. Personally, I didn't bother with monsters in this game and never did until Disgaea 3 (looks at Vita). They can be decently powerful, but I preferred to field Majins and Angels (top tier unit classes) instead. Hell, I considered them underpowered in this game - but this is just PERSONAL preference. Your milage may differ. Geo Panels also add a depth to the tactics, making some squares on the field have special effects. One effect might damage 20% hp of a unit standing on the square. Another might heal 20% instead. Or it might even be Invincibility. It could cover the map or it could just be a 9x9 grid on a map 5x that. Or it might be all over the frickin place.

Grinding is pretty fun in this game, compared to grind for the sake of grinding type games. The Item World, a hallmark of the Disgaea series, allows you to delve into an item to clear random maps in it (30, 60, 100 floors for common, rare, legendary items) and power it up. It's an excellent waste of time.



Summary
Some assumptions made. Figure it's a direct port of PSP or DS version to PC. May be missing stuff like optional Japanese voicing.

Pros:
+ A horse weiner?! Now THAT'S dangerous! Be careful guys!" - Larhal. Great humor.
+ Excellent gameplay
date:
great storyline.
+ Balances seriousness and humor perfectly.
+ Great music score.
+ Can take as little as 40-60 hours or as many as several thousand depending on you.
+ Can turn off animations when you get bored of it. No waiting 30 seconds just to see you one shot every enemy in a 3x3 grid.
+ Can turn on Japanese voices.

Cons:
- Monsters never felt good to me. Lack of weapon mastery gimped them far too much in my books.
- Flonne's English voice actor hurt my ears at times.
- Lacks challenge past a certain point
recommended: but you'd be done with postgame stuff and probably grinding Item World to perfect items at this point.\n- Lacks character recolor system
hoursPlayed: added into later games. Means all your characters of the same class and tier will look the same.\n- If it's the PSP port
voteText: lacks the option to recruit Plenair
helpfulPercent: the mascot character of the sprite designer responsible for the Disgaea series' characters.\n- Feels slightly choppy on full widescreen (i7 3770
votesHelpful: GTX 660
votesTotal:
8GB RAM). Smooth on windowed. Can resize the windowed though.
- They didn't bother to put in a Y/Triangle button skip function for the opening sequence - again. Oh well.

You decide:
-+ If you go with the time wasting and postgame stuff
votesFunny: your party will probably consist exclusively of Majins and/or Angels. You CAN use other stuff
commentsCount: but these are the two powerhouses of the game
column16: unlocked after a bit of grinding.\n\nNow
column18: I'm off on a trip down memory lane.\n\nPS: For the people that have played this before and just got it on PC because reasons
column19: can confirm Etna Mode code works (using a 360 controller but whatever
column20: probably works with the keyboard bindings)."

reviewText:
It is an absolute joy to return to play it again. I still have my copy for the DS that I love so very much so it's good to have it in my hands with full voice acting. The DS release sadly had very little to speak of for voicing due to the limitations it had, but the PC version made me overjoyed to hear more dialogue read aloud by the characters.

Controls are as expected. Takes getting use to for directions on the map, but once you're good you're good. Battles run pretty smooth, haven't noticed any glitches thus far. And yeah, the resolution of the sprites and weapons might be an issue to some, but it's a port so that's not an issue in my book.

All in all it's an enjoyable game, and if you're looking to enjoy a good strategy JRPG with some comical humor and chapter base story and tons of hidden quests to take on then this is definitely worth a look at.

reviewText:
There seems to be problems with some pc configurations. That was not my case.

Runs perfectly without slowdowns. Disable SSAO filter (is completely broken), the blur and the character filter and just enjoy it. The new map textures and lightning don't clash too much with the old character sprites. The new ui has some rough spots but it can be considered a great improvement over what we had on psp and the new graphics for cutscenes are really great.

And oh my god! Mouse support T_T at least for me has worked perfectly. It's not the most practical way of playing this game but it's something i've always desired.

Any way buy it, test it until the tutorials (less than two hours) and if it doesn't work just refund because the technical problems seem to be something with specific computer configurations.

P.S. Yes it lacks some options to fine tune resolution and the button prompts are not shown correctly even if they have prompts in the game for any kind of keyboard key.

reviewText:
So far my only gripe with it is that SSAO and Shadows seems to murder the framerate. You'd think a game from over 10 years ago wouldnt do that much damage even with new graphical features. But nope, im hitting 100% GPU usage sometimes, And it will lock itself at 30fps sometimes. Which, incidentally, the framerate is tied to the speed of the game, So you'll have to quit to the menu and reload unless you like playing a game at halfspeed.

It could be worse I suppose. I imagine Nis America doesn't usually export 10 year old games from the PS2 over to PC, so like i said, it could have been a disaster with the amount of experience they had to work with.

Other than that, its a great updated version of the original and im very much looking forward to completing the game...without ssao and shadows to maintain that 60fps.

reviewText:
This game is a wonderful JRPG made back in 2003 for the PS2. Since then this game has been ported to the PSP, DS, and now the PC. I have played all of the other versions of this game and i enjoy it very much. Its a turn based tile system similar to Fire Emblem games. This game does feature plenty of level grinding though so you may find that tedious. Now to focus more on this specific port; It has changed keybindings into numbers 1,2,3 etc. and use those to direct you on what to do and it is the same for a controller (atleast xbox360). The game is shown at 60fps but there were times during some cutscenes where the frames dropped to 30 and the entire cutscene slowed to half speed.

TLDR
Pros:
fun JRPG
Competent port
Similar to Fire Emblem
9999 levels
PLENTY OF PLAY TIME AVAILABLE
Funny story
Depth in combat featuring geo panels
A giant RANDOM dungeon that changes anytime you want to enter it (very well done)

Cons:
Frame drops that slowed cutscenes down to 50% speed occasionaly
Lots of level grinding if you dont enjoy it
(may or may not have all of the features of the latest port [DS] i will update the review when i can find out)

Buy this game its fun
(tell me anything i need to edit on my review if you find something wrong or something i missed)

reviewText:
Will provide a more detailed review as time goes by - however I have (between the PS2 and PSP versions of this game) several hundred if not thousands of hours played so I -know- that the game is a solid recommend for me - it's whether the port is reliable. On a first glance (what, nearly an hour?) I've not had a single issue.

In a weird twist from a Japanese developer porting a console game to PC, the controls are actually surprisingly intuitive, not to mention actually listed with keyboard keys rather than controller keys in the game itself (I hate games that tell me to press X when they mean the controller X not the keyboard X, a minor pet peeve of mine).

Audio seems to have been remastered somewhat - though I could be just remembering the PSP's not so stellar audio.

All in all, if you like Disgaea games it's worth the buy - if you have any of the currently reported FPS issues you can refund it, and most of the graphics bugs are related to the new graphics options (which, in my opinion are not needed anyway); these can all be turned off in the menu.

and to top it off, that one super zombie even has a horse weiner!

seriously, if you want to say goodbye to the next 4-5 years of your life trying to max out your characters (or longer) look no further. For playability, replay, and potential gaming hours, this legendary gem of a game delivers.
I can only hope to see the sequels make it to pc as well.
Also, this is a Strategy RPG, like Record of Agarest war, except with more depth for character development.
The classes of characters, both human and monster, are too numerous to list here, as well as item world residents...
yes. item world residents. they live in your items, and make them stronger. you can level them up, as well as your items.
levelling, levelling, levelling! Think you're maxed out at level 9999 with all your skills maxed? nuh uh... you can start over at level 1 and carry over all the bonuses, as any class/monster you want, and retain 95% of everything you gained, with additional points to become even more godly.

note: as this is in beta, the only...ONLY... downside I've seen is occaisional crashing. usually right before saving.
but, if you're an old hand to these games, you know to save every chance you get after every minor action you do if/when you can. that way the most you'll lose is maybe a 1/2 hour from doing an item world speed run.
If all this still doesn't have you sold, just remember:
Zombie with a horse weiner.

reviewText: I love this game. It was a bummer that it had such a bad launch but seriously the game has become tons better. As a person who has played the PS2 and DS version. But you know what the story line, antics of the characters, and just the shear ammount of hours and playability in the game make it VERY worth the 20 bucks you will pay for this game. If you are an SRPG fan then grab Disgaea and have fun. trust me you won't regret it.

reviewText:
Long time player of the Disgaea series along with Phantom Brave, LaPucelle Tactics and Makai Kingdom, Laharl is my favorite protagonist of them all actually, but I just cannot get back into the game.  If you are just looking for something old to play or just want a goofy story, then ya you might enjoy playing this one.  Sadly a terrible port, so many things can go wrong.  Of course the typical stuck up Japanses gaming companies that seem to not give a darn about their console to pc ports or the gaming community recently for that matter is strong with this one!  Sad to see NIS a company that I once purchased a lot of game from go down this route.  Crashing in the middle of Item World causes a lot of heart burn!

Of course the good old grind is there, but the disgaea series typically makes grinding less painful if you just want the story, but if you are going for the haul of perfecting your items, characters, & monsters then you are in for some long long nights.

Sadly the game still has terrible balance issues, if you know how to farm well you can power level in the item world if you look out for the stages where clone and invicibility are together, and while this is not as easy as it may sound, just a single good farm of this stage and you can litterally power level several units by hundreds of levels at a time heck and not even go past the first chapter.

But it does have to be said... no one does tactical turnbased combat as well as Disgaea.   At least in my opinion, but at the end of the day, this game is just too long in the tooth, maybe if the port was better or they actually upgraded the sprites too I would give it a thumbs up, but all things being equal, pick it up on discount.  It does not serve the gaming comunity if we keep buying minimal effort rehashed games at full price!

reviewText:
The first game in the series and one of the best as well.
I have noticed that some people are getting issues with the game regarding pauses, graphical issues, etc... but I have yet to get any of those.
Pros:
The story is amazingly funny.
You don't have to use the main characters at all.
You can make your own team and have them be whatever they want even if it's a mage with guns.
Music is really nice and fitting. Some catchy tunes that you'll never forget.
New user interface makes the pictures of the characters and the text much more readable.
Map texture is also updated and looks fantastic!
Can mix interface if you prefer older style, nothing is forced onto you.
Can still switch between Japanese and English voice acting.
Game is not FPS locked.
I can throw people into other people.

Cons:
May sometimes pause during new interface dialouge for about 1 second.
Low end computers might not get great performance.
Can't jump.

Neutral:
Some graphical glitches with new interface, but nothing game breaking.
Horse weiner.

As a fan I give the game busting balls/10...
as a non-proffesional reviewer of games I give it 8.8/10. :D

reviewText:
Well, I've already played the PS2 and PSP version, so I'm not going to spoil story or other details, so let me get on to whether it's a terrible port as rags like Destructoid have been claiming.

For me, NO.

SSAO and Depth of Field are terrible, turn them off, this needs patched, but the game doesn't need it and runs as well as it's other versions did. Otherwise, it looks sharper and cleaner with ther new interface and has nicer resolution. Voice acting is about PS2 quality, which was above average at worst.

It's playable with the keyboard and mouse, but I definitely recommend a PS2 style controller or something similiar for optimal fun.

I haven't had any other issues and it's still the amazingly fun game it was on other platforms, don't regret pre-ordering this at all.

reviewText:
5/10:  What would otherwise be a fantastic game is otherwise badly marred by excessive bugs... almost unplayable.

The game is extremely prone to random crashes, especially if you (or the enemy) use any special moves, combo attacks, or geo-effect color changes.  Since this is all an absolutely key, integral part of the game, and you cannot save or exit the item world until completing a grueling 10 levels or abandoning progress completely, you will find you cannot actually progress in most cases-  6 out of 7 times, it will crash on me before you finish.

The gameplay itself is enjoyable-  very in-depth, many things to collect and customize, fun characters and classes, colorful if simple, mostly 2D visuals, and great music.
It is, however, rather tedious-  a game focused on grinding levels-  and the story is extremely lacking and ditzy.  The sound is very, very repetative and obnoxious, with voice-acting that in either English OR Japanese will make you claw your ears off-  you know, the typical obnoxious, whiny child voices noone ever wanted to hear.

Graphics:  7/10
Music:  10/10
Sound:  2/10
Gameplay:  7/10
Stability:  1/10
Total:  26/50

Frankly, this would have been a good game, but we're THREE patches in and it's still a bust.   If they fixed the crashes, it would bring it up a good few points.  Overall, I have to give it a 5 out of 10.

reviewText:
Let me preface this by saying I've played Disgaea as a series for eight years or so. I have beaten the first game several times, and have characters in the high four thousands on various platforms.

The game itself is amazing and fun, and they've added some interesting graphical doodads.

That said, this port is missing several features.

- Text speed control
- Battle speed control

As it is, they are on their default, slowest settings and as someone who has played the first four games a lot, this is driving me nuts.

If they implement the two changes mentioned above, I'll certainly change to a positive review. It's Disgaea, but it shouldn't make me feel like the Game Boy Advance port of Final Fantasy IV.

Day 1, it was broken mess for many.
Today, it's getting better but there's still random crash here and there.
Saving anytime you can ( and thanksfully you can save anytime you want when not in battle ) lessen the problem, but the problem is still here and can get pretty annoying when trying to get the achievement that require to play at least 1+h straight in the item world without saving...

==Music Stuff==
Probably one of the best point of the game. Music from NIS / Tenpei Sato are of excellent quality

==Graph Stuff==
10+ years ago, it was decent at best. nowadays, it's the kind of thing you'd expect from low budget indie game.
While there has been a few enhancement here and there from the PSP version, it's still far from being up to nowadays standard

==Scenario==
Mostly comedy with some seriousness here and there.

==Gameplay Stuff==
Basic is a good word for it. There's nothing exceptionnal here.
If you played a more recent Disgaea game on PS3/4, then you'll most likely find this game completly primitive.

==Replayability==
Wholly depend wether you intend to grind for the post game or not.
10 to 15 hours top are plenty enough to clear the storyline.
Add 15 to 30 hours of stats/item grinding/leveling to defeat the last Ex Boss.

==Overall==
10+ years ago, this game was a solid hit. Today, there are many other better game available but it's still would be a decent one to spend a few hours i'd recommand if it wasn't for those annoying random crash.

( Once NIS America fix that problem, I'll edit this review to positive. )

reviewText:
A semi-adequate port.  Not bad, definitely not terrible, but when core functionality does not work properly (eg dodgy mouse controls) you cannot call it good.  Serviceable at best.

The art is nice, the music surprisingly good and the plot quite entertaining.  Humour is always YMMV, but I liked it.  It definitely helps to have at least a basic appreciation for the Japanese TV references.  The core gameplay, however, was disappointing.  It is a decent Tactical RPG, a genre barely represented on PC, but compared to its peers there are some serious issues.  The way experience is handled cripples certain classes and emphasises one or two over-powered Rambo characters over a balanced and tactial squad (the normal for the genre).  This makes a lot of the potential gameplay elements irrelevant, because attempting to explore them weakens you and makes the game more grindy/less fun.  The randomised Item World maps are an interesting concept, but can occationally be impossible to complete, resulting in wasted time.

There is a market for this game, but I think it is a very small one.  Combined with the not-so-good port, I believe this is a game most people could safely pass over.
